conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph to determine if the difference in speed between two objects is continuously increasing.
The graph shows two curves, A and B, representing the velocities of two objects as functions of time.
The difference in speed is the vertical distance between curves A and B at any given time.
At t = 0, both curves start at the same point, so the difference in speed is zero.
As time progresses from 0 to t1, the vertical distance between the curves increases, reaches a maximum, and then decreases back to zero at t1.
Initially, the difference in speed increases as curve A rises faster than curve B.
After reaching a maximum difference, the difference starts to decrease as curve B begins to catch up to curve A.
At t1, the difference in speed returns to zero, indicating that the objects have the same speed again.
The difference in speed between the two objects does not continuously increase from 0 to t1.
Final answer: No, the difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
